title: Health Retreat Run By Banned Wellness Coach Under Investigation
text:
A woman who told people that cancer is a fungus that can be cured with bicarbonate soda is having her health retreat investigated by Australia's charities watchdog after a series of complaints were lodged about the Misty Mountain Health Retreat.

Wellness coach Barbara O'Neill was banned last month from practising as a naturopath, nutritionist and health educator for life after giving potentially fatal advice to vulnerable clients, also including misleading and dangerous advice on pregnancy and child nutrition, via her seminars, website, online lectures and one-on-one consultations.

The Australian Charities and Not-for-profits Commission (Acnc) has received several complaints about the Misty Mountain Health Retreat, which is affiliated with O'Neill, and which her husband Michael O'Neill is the chair.

In its capacity as an Acnc-registered health promotion charity, Misty Mountain Health Retreat benefits from government grants and tax concessions. The retreat reports that it operates live-in health centres in New South Wales, Victoria and Queensland where Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people and people living with chronic and terminal illnesses receive diet, exercise and health advice.

Michael O'Neill also founded the Involuntary Medication Objectors (Vaccination/Fluoride) Party, and ran for the Senate in this year's federal election. The party is unsurprisingly anti-vax and not a fan of conventional medicine.

The Guardian reports a complaint made to Acnc alleges the Misty Mountain Health Retreat's activities don't align with its report, stating that it “operates what is effectively a wellness holiday resort”.

“Misty Mountain Health Retreat's unqualified staff give its clients erroneous advice,” the complaint made by dietician and nutritionist Mandy-Lee Noble, states. “The clients are at risk if they act on it.”

Noble’s complaint alleges that Michael O’Neill’s political involvement was a conflict of interest with health promotion.

The Health Care Complaints Commission investigation into Barbara O'Neill found she never held any membership with any accredited professional health organisation and had no relevant health-related degrees or diplomas.

She has been permanently banned from providing any health services, including lectures, and has announced to her supporters she is currently staying overseas with relatives with no immediate plans to return to Australia. There is no evidence she has been practising since being banned.

An Acnc spokesman The Guardian, “The Acnc takes all concerns seriously and will investigate if there is evidence that a charity has failed to comply with its obligations.”
description: Several complaints have been received about the Misty Mountain Health Retreat.
